ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a broader vocabulary and more advanced Indonesian speaking techniques.
Learned about Indonesian language and culture
I learned important speaking and writing skills in the Indonesian language.
Becoming more fluent in the Indonesian language
How to speak Indonesian. Deeper grammatical structures than L1 and more culture.
Understanding of Indonesian
Good understanding of both the Indonesian culture and language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very interesting and engaging and I found myself enjoying going to class every day. There were some points where I had to clarify what the assignment was or when an assignment was due because it was not very clear, but I very much so enjoyed this course.

Strengths: the class
Weaknesses: there are none. Indonesian with Pak Indriyo is the best
This class could not have been taught better
Best language at Yale. Pak Indriyo is an icon. This class was truly a bright spot in my day every day. Even though Indonesian was early, I looked forward to it every day.
Fun class, but bad communication and able to see your grades.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There were plenty of activities in class that kept us all engaged, which was very effective, however, there were times where an in-person class would have benefitted us a little more that you just couldn't achieve online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This course was very fun and interesting. Pak Indriyo is an awesome professor and does a great job teaching the language.
Yes 100%
Yes. This class is amazing. Not only do you learn the indonesian language but you also engage with its culture
Yes, because the curriculum was introduced in a very clear and straightforward way.
Yes this course has been one of my favorites at Yale
Best language at Yale. Pak Indriyo is an icon. This class was truly a bright spot in my day every day. Even though Indonesian was early, I looked forward to it every day.
Yes, it is a fun class with a fun teacher, but still hard because it  is a new language and there is a lot or oral exams. Our final was a 50 minute oral exam.
Yes! Professor is great and really helps you understand the material.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Ngobral!
none
